Caring for a child with SEND can be rewarding and challenging. You do not have to do it alone. There is support available for the whole family.

Short breaks

Short breaks give disabled children and their families time apart. They range from a few hours of activities for your child to overnight or residential care.

Short breaks help your child develop skills and confidence, and give you and your family time to rest and recharge.

What is available

  • after-school and holiday clubs for disabled children
  • weekend activities and outings
  • overnight stays (with a carer or in a residential setting)
  • support in the family home

Your right to short breaks

The council has a legal duty to provide a range of short breaks for disabled children and their families. This is set out in the Breaks for Carers of Disabled Children Regulations 2011.

Parent carer forums

Parent carer forums are groups of parents and carers of children with SEND who work together to improve local services. They are run by parents, for parents.

Joining a parent carer forum can help you:

  • meet other families who understand what you are going through
  • share experiences and advice
  • have a say in how local SEND services are planned and delivered
  • get involved in shaping the Local Offer

The council is legally required to consult the parent carer forum when reviewing the Local Offer and making decisions about SEND services.

Support for you as a carer

Carer's assessment

As a parent or carer of a child with SEND, you may be entitled to a carer's assessment of your own needs. This looks at what support you need to continue caring, including your own health, work and wellbeing.

You can request a carer's assessment from the council at any time. You do not have to be receiving any other services to ask for one.

Looking after yourself

It is important to look after your own wellbeing. You may find it helpful to:

  • connect with other parents through local support groups
  • take advantage of short breaks when they are available
  • ask for a carer's assessment if you are struggling
  • contact SENDIASS for advice on navigating the SEND system

Independent supporters

Independent supporters are trained people who can help families navigate the EHC assessment and planning process. They provide practical, hands-on support to help you through the paperwork, meetings and decisions.

They are different from SENDIASS because they provide ongoing practical support rather than information and advice. Contact the SEND team to find out what is currently available in Gloucestershire.

Other services that may help

Children's social care

If your child has needs under the Children Act 1989 (as a child in need, for example), they may also get support from children's social care alongside their SEND support.

School attendance support

Children with SEND are at greater risk of missing school. If your child is struggling to attend, the Education Welfare service can help.

Home education

If you choose to educate your child at home, the council still has a duty to secure the provision in their EHC plan. Your child's name stays on the plan.

You matter too

As a carer, you have the right to request an assessment of your own support needs. You do not have to wait to be offered one.
